Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:Evolutionary flexibility of hormone systems and behavior
Award.AbstractNarration: Biologists still don't understand the mechanisms by which genetic and environmental influences interact to produce well-functioning organisms. This project takes advantage of the wealth of research on stress hormones in the Trinidadian guppy (Poecilia reticulata) to ask how differences in stress hormones coordinate favorable changes in traits influenced by these hormones such as behavior, color, and body size. To address these questions, the project measures hormone levels and various behaviors in fish reared in the laboratory using a breeding design that distinguishes the effects of genetic background and rearing environment. The project will reveal how long- and short-term environmental differences alter hormone levels and the consequences of changes in hormone levels on traits that influence guppy survival. The results will reveal the hormonal mechanisms by which genes and the environment interact to shape multiple traits. In addition, hormone levels - in particular stress hormone levels - are often used to predict health and fitness in wild and domestic animals, and understanding how genetics and environment interact to modify levels in natural populations will improve predictions of how animals respond to novel or changing environments, such as habitat degradation, invasive species, and climate change. This dissertation improvement grant will support the training of a graduate student and research involvement of multiple undergraduate students. The project will also reach out to local middle and high schools using guppies as a model for inquiry-based science in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A central question in biology is how organisms adapt to new and changing environments. The goal of this project was to explore mechanisms underlying evolution. We wanted to know whether many mechanisms cause changes in behavior, or the same mechanisms are reused every time behavior shifts. We used the Trinidadian guppy, Poecilia reticulata, to conduct this work. Guppies are small, fresh water fish native to South American. On the island of Trinidad, guppies exist in environments with and without predators. To survive in these different environments, guppies must alter their body size and shape, color patterns, and behavior. Guppies are unique because they can make these changes more quickly than other animals. We explored changes in the brain associated with shifts in behavior. We found that multiple mechanisms can cause similar changes in behavior. We believe this flexibility helps guppies adapt and evolve rapidly. By expanding our work to other animals we hope to understand how animals respond to new and changing environments. This question is important given widespread habitat destruction and climate change. 

 

We also work to get more K-12 students excited about science. Many students lose interest in science long before college. Increasing diversity at the university level requires reaching out to students of all ages. We have designed and tested a program that uses guppies as a model for hands-on science in the public school classroom. We use guppies to teach students about ecology, evolution, and the scientific method. Students then design, conduct, and present group research projects using live fish. This program helps students learn and explore their scientific creativity.
